Posted By: PhantomDust (1/22/2012 11:45:41 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@pumaman83 This card is not useless 99.9% of the time. In limited, regardless of whether it is a "soulshift" deck, it is good against all spirits, which is half of the creatures. Also now with Inninstrad block you have Spirits making a comeback. Also @SirZapados hits the nail on the head when he states how to properly combo this card. Which makes it handy if not useful.  
  
Also, as far as comparison to [Rod of Ruin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rod of Ruin), yeah Rod of Ruin is better as a stand alone card, but mix it in with creature type changing cards like [Imagecrafter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Imagecrafter), [Unnatural Selection](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unnatural Selection), [Mistform Mutant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mistform Mutant), [Wings of Velis Vel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wings of Velis Vel), or [Trickery Charm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Trickery Charm). Unfortunately they are all blue.  
  
And before anyone states the obvious arguement of when you combo most cards they become better. I know that, but many cards are rated the way they are, not because of their stand alone value, but because of their combo value.  
  
I ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
OpenSeasonNoobs pegs this card's problem while trying to defend it. The only time this card is EVER even a little bit useful is against "a well built soulshift deck". That means this is a card that is worthless 99.9% of the time but may slightly disrupt that one guy somewhere that has a decent soulshift deck.
  
   
Thus the ever crappy Rod of Ruin really is better because it is more useful against every deck other than that "well built soulshift deck"
